Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Create Effective COVID-19 Chatbots through High Patient Engagement Phase I
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide on-demand customized health information. Chatbots are automated communication agents that have been successful in other sectors, but to date they have enjoyed limited success in patient engagement during the COVID-19 pandemic. Increased patient engagement leads to better health outcomes and cost savings. This project will develop a COVID-19 chatbot to address common questions and transactions, freeing healthcare staff for more complex cases and providing information to patients seeking to minimize office visits during periods of social distancing. <br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance development of patient engagement via chatbots. This project represents a chatbot as a graph of states, wherein a transition is based on the user message. The proposed chatbot optimizer extends this model by applying reinforcement learning to dynamically compute the best response given the user profile and context. The objective of the optimizer is to reach a success state (for example, make an appointment with a counselor), accounting for the fact that a user (patient) may drop out at any time; previous work on goal-oriented chatbots has generally not included this possibility.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to improve the quality of chatbot responses, to increase user engagement and decrease user drop-out. The drop-out rate is defined as how many of the users (e.g. patients) quit using the chatbot before satisfying their informational or transactional need.

Intellectual merit: This project reduces user drop-out rates by employing (a) user- and context-aware response generation, and (b) a multi-tier response generation algorithm.

Regarding Aim (a), we succeeded in creating a chatbot optimizer that defines the possible actions of a goal-oriented bot, and automatically learns how to best respond to an end-user message to maximize the probability of reaching the goal of the bot. The chatbot optimizer employs reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms to learn the best response given the user profile, the context, and the history of the chat so far.  For Aim (b), we built a smart multi-tier response algorithm. Specifically, given the current context and the last user utterance, our algorithm first looks for an answer in the bot flow diagram, and if there is no response it tries to match the user utterance to one of the question-answer pairs in the bot’s knowledge base. We use state-of-the-art deep learning techniques to compute the relevance of an utterance to the query.

Broader Impacts: The developed technology has the potential to increase the efficiency of the communication between patients and the healthcare system, which is particularly important in addressing healthcare disparities. In particular, healthcare chatbots allow providers to scale their reach to more patients at lower cost.
